snippet: Long avoided by courts in the United States, locked docks are widely used elsewhere, even in cases where the defendants do not seem particularly dangerous.
abstract: Locked docks in courtrooms are still common, not only in countries like Russia and Egypt where the judicial systems often face international criticism, but also in many Western democracies; practice is coming under new scrutiny by legal experts and rights advocates, who say the potential harm of implying guilt has multiplied now that court proceedings are often broadcast live.
lead_paragraph: Long avoided by courts in the United States, locked docks are widely used elsewhere, even in cases where the defendants do not seem particularly dangerous.

headline.main: Presumed Innocent, but Caged in Court
headline.print_headline: Presumed Innocent, But Caged In Court

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
